description: Kathmandu Durbar Square is a UNESCO World Heritage Site located about two kilometers from the thermal area and a 10 to 15 minutes drive depending on the traffic. The entire area is dotted with temples, palaces, and towers that are very beautiful. Some are seriously damaged by the recent earthquake and are being restored, but few temples are functional. The square features an open-air souvenir marketplace called person portable e-square. The area has access to several hotels and restaurants.
fun_fact: The Kumari girl is the home of the Kumari or living goddess who is considered to be an incarnation of the goddess Taleju.

cultural_activities.details: The Kumari appears from time to time in the company of her guardian Priestess to see and to be seen by her admirers.
Visitors can explore various temples including the Shiva Parvati Temple, Indra Put Temple, and Taleju Temple.

description: Kathmandu Durbar Square is located in the heart of capital Kathmandu. It is one of the three durbar squares in the capital, the other being Patan Durbar Square and Bhaktapur Durbar Square. Unlike the other two durbar squares, this one served as the home for the kings of our country Nepal. After the unification, a big palace was built within the area for the kings to live in, but as of now it serves as a museum. Kathmandu Durbar Square is often known as a place where different kings ruled our country for generations. It is also a home to the living goddess Kumari. The area is a host to a lot of interesting local festivals throughout the year, with Indra Jatra being one of the very well-known festivals that goes on for a week straight. The temples and monuments are mostly made up of woods, bricks, and adobe clay, and most of them date back to the 17th century. Being an open place in the middle of a busy city, it is considered a good place for the locals to hang out.
fun_fact: The current Kumari is just about 6 years of age now.
